The most recent multi-year authorization for federal surface transportation programs, SAFETEA-LU, expired in 2009. Since then, programs have operated on extensions due to constrained financial resources. The highway trust fund, funded by gasoline and diesel taxes, has declined, leading to debates on passing a bill without cutting spending, raising taxes, or increasing the deficit. Alternative finance and tolling are also key issues in the ongoing debate. The ongoing debate in Congress revolves around passing a multi-year bill for surface transportation programs without cutting infrastructure spending, raising the gas tax, or increasing the budget deficit. Other issues being discussed include alternative finance, tolling, public-private partnerships, project delivery acceleration, and performance management. The distribution of federal spending among states is also a concern, with challenges in resolving equity due to forecasted revenues. The Senate passed MAP-21 in 2012 to reauthorize surface transportation programs for two years. The House committees reported favorably on H.R. 7, a five-year bill authorizing $260 billion for surface transportation programs. The bill includes provisions to increase oil and gas production to fund highway infrastructure, controversially discontinuing mass transit funding from Highway Trust Fund revenues. The House also passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II, extending authorizations through FY2012. The House passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II (H.R. 4348) on April 18, 2012, extending surface transportation authorizations through the end of FY2012. The Senate later replaced the House language with MAP-21, leading to negotiations involving the entire substance of H.R. 7 and provisions of the extension bill. The highway trust fund is financed through various sources, with the majority coming from excise taxes on motor fuels. The fund consists of separate accounts for highways and mass transit, with specific allocations from fuel taxes. Fuel taxes do not adjust for inflation as they are set in cents per gallon. The highway trust fund is facing a shortfall due to stagnant fuel tax revenues and increased expenses. The fund has required transfers from the general fund to cover costs, and projections show a significant gap in funding through 2022. The mass transit account is also at risk of running out of funds. The CBO projections indicate a significant shortfall in the highway account, with a gap of $8 to $9 billion per year through 2022. The mass transit account is projected to fall into a negative $1.2 billion shortfall by the end of FY2014, with further deepening deficits in the following years. Without an increase in fuel taxes, policymakers must find new revenue sources for transportation or settle for a smaller program. The Federal-Aid Highway Program faces financial challenges and administrative issues. The Federal-Aid Highway Program (Highway Program) is a state-run program administered by FHWA, with states determining spending but following federal guidelines. Projects require a state/local matching share, with Interstate System projects at 10% and other roads at 20%. Funds are distributed through FHWA notifications, not upfront payments to states. Managing the Highway Program involves distributing funds through FHWA notifications, apportioning funds among states, allocating funds for specific projects, and providing reimbursement once a project is approved and costs are incurred. Highway safety is a major concern in the United States, with federal highway safety programs administered by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA), and FHWA.
